codeExamples.title: ADC background scan source
codeExamples.name: ADC_Background_Scan_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:
The Background Scan mode of the Analog-to-Digital Converter (ADC) module is configured to measure the
analog signals applied to the channels 4 to 7 of the group 4.
codeExamples.abstract: The Versatile Analog-to-Digital Converter (VADC) is configured to measure multiple analog signals in a sequence using background scan request.

codeExamples.title: ADC background scan source
codeExamples.name: ADC_Background_Scan_1_KIT_TC297_TFT
codeExamples.description:
The Background Scan mode of the Analog-to-Digital Converter (ADC) module is configured to measure the
analog signals applied to the channels 0 to 3 of the group 0.
codeExamples.abstract: The Versatile Analog-to-Digital Converter (VADC) is configured to measure multiple analog signals in a sequence using background scan request.

codeExamples.title: ADC filtering
codeExamples.name: ADC_Filtering_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:
The Versatile Analog-to-Digital Converter (VADC) module is configured to convert four channels in
background scan mode. The data resulting from the conversions of three channels is automatically
modified: one channel computes an average on 4 results, another channel applies a 3rd order
Finite Impulse Response (FIR) filter and another channel applies a 1st order
Infinite Impulse Response (IIR) filter. Finally, the last channel measures the same signal without
Data Modification. The channels are continuously converted and, for each of them, the maximum
and minimum values are stored, which are then sent through UART in order to be compared.
codeExamples.abstract: Four VADC channels are used to convert the same analog signal with different filters enabled.

codeExamples.title: Auto Scan of ADC channel
codeExamples.name: ADC_Group_Scan_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:
The Auto Scan mode of the Versatile Analog to Digital Converter (VADC) module is enabled over the
channels 0 to 4 of the Group 0. Additionally, the converted results are checked with the
Valid Flag (VF) of the Result Register, and then sent to the PC via UART.
codeExamples.abstract: The Versatile Analog-to-Digital Converter (VADC) is configured to measure multiple analog signals in a sequence using  scan request.

codeExamples.title: ADC single channel conversion
codeExamples.name: ADC_Single_Channel_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:
An analog input channel is continuously converted using the background scan mode.
The input value is determined by the potentiometer on the board.
Two LEDs are used to indicate a voltage interval.
Thus depending on the conversion value, one or both LEDs are on.
codeExamples.abstract: The Versatile Analog-to-Digital Converter (VADC) is configured to measure an analog signal using background scan request.

codeExamples.title: ADC single channel conversion
codeExamples.name: ADC_Single_Channel_1_KIT_TC297_TFT
codeExamples.description:
An analog input channel is continuously converted using the background scan mode. The input value
is determined using the microcontroller's supply voltage, ground level or letting the analog pin open
and floating. Three LEDs are used, each indicating a voltage interval. Thus depending on the conversion
value, a certain LED will light up.
codeExamples.abstract: The Versatile Analog-to-Digital Converter (VADC) is configured to measure an analog signal using background scan request.

codeExamples.title: Shell via UART communication
codeExamples.name: ASCLIN_Shell_UART_1_KIT_TC237_TFT
codeExamples.description:
The ASCLIN module is configured for UART communication.
The Shell from iLLDs exploits the ASCLIN module to interpret and manage commands from the
user like "info", "toggle [x]" or "help".
codeExamples.abstract: A Shell is used to parse a command line and call the corresponding command execution. The ASCLIN module is used to interface with the Shell through the USB port via UART.

codeExamples.title: GTM to TGO signal routing
codeExamples.name: BMETAL_TC375_ADS_GTM_TIM_TGO_Debug

codeExamples.abstract: This example demonstrates how the GTM signals can be routed to OCDS trigger output pins TGO.

codeExamples.title: BMETAL_TC375_ADS_WSS_GTM_TSSM_HW
codeExamples.name: BMETAL_TC375_ADS_WSS_GTM_TSSM_HW
codeExamples.description: The TIM block within the GTM is used to decode the AK protocol. The are five TIM channels used in this example, three of them perform the manchester decoding, the fourth is used to measure the period of the speed pulse signal and the fifth is used to count the number of bits transmitted in the AK frame for handling the shorten frame.
codeExamples.abstract: This is a demo code for interfacing the TLE5046iC Wheel Speed Sensor (WSS) using GTM block, the AK protocol is decoded by the GTM-TIM using TSSM mode of operation

codeExamples.title: BMETAL_TC377_ADS_EVADC_Daisy_Chain_1
codeExamples.name: BMETAL_TC377_ADS_EVADC_Daisy_Chain_1
codeExamples.description: Daisy Chain can be used to connect conversions on multiple EVADC instances. Note, the same queue entry shall be used on each participating EVADC.
codeExamples.abstract: This example demonstrates the daisy chain method, to connect multiple conversions on different EVADC groups using just one trigger.

codeExamples.title: BMETAL_TC377_ADS_EVADC_Master_Slave_1
codeExamples.name: BMETAL_TC377_ADS_EVADC_Master_Slave_1
codeExamples.description:
This example demonstrates how to properly configure multiple EVADC groups (up to 4, within the same synchronization group) for master-slave synchronous conversion. In addition, Alias feature (channel redirection) is explained, too.

The master will trigger the same channel(s) on the slave(s) at the same time. If other channel is expected, "Alias feature" will help.
codeExamples.abstract: TC3xx EVADC master-slave synchronous conversion and Alias feature

codeExamples.title: BMETAL_TC387_ADS_EDSADC_FIFO_1
codeExamples.name: BMETAL_TC387_ADS_EDSADC_FIFO_1
codeExamples.description:
This bare metal code example initializes TC387 EDSADC and its FIFO.
Every time when the FIFO is full (with 4 results in single-word read mode, DRM = 0), an interrupt is triggered and results are fetched from FIFO.
A 100ns wait is inserted between each read (the first read after interrupt does not need wait). See user manual chapter "Result Service Request Generation and Read Sequencing" foot note.
Corresponding FIFO error bits are checked when reading results, in order to ensure data integrity.
codeExamples.abstract: Bare metal code example to initialize TC387 EDSADC, its FIFO, interrupt and FIFO read.

codeExamples.title: BMETAL_TC4D7_LITE_ADS_TMADC_Timestamp_1
codeExamples.name: BMETAL_TC4D7_LITE_ADS_TMADC_Timestamp_1
codeExamples.description: The TC4x Time-Multiplexed Analog-to-Digital Converter (TMADC) generates a timestamp for each new conversion result (the time point when the sampling phase finishes) to qualify the result. The timestamp has a fixed resolution of 200ns. This demo shows the generated timestamps for user's reference.
codeExamples.abstract: This example demonstrates how to generate timestamp for each new TMADC result.

codeExamples.title: Register Access Protection
codeExamples.name: BUS_Register_Protection_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:
The CPU0 tries to make a write access to an ASCLIN0 module register two times: when the access is
enabled for CPU0 and when the access is disabled for CPU0. During the second register write access,
a Trap is expected to be raised, to inform about the illegal write access.
codeExamples.abstract: This example shows how to protect registers from unintended write access by using AURIX register access protection mechanisms.

codeExamples.title: CCU6 ADC conversion triggering
codeExamples.name: CCU6_ADC_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:
The Timer T12 is defining the Analog-to-Digital Converter (ADC) sample rate. Due to the instability of
the signals (e.g. the overshoot period), a delay is introduced by Timer T13 after each period match of
Timer T12. This ensures that the measurement is done when the signal is already stable. UART
communication is used to display all measured values on a terminal monitor.
codeExamples.abstract: CCU6 timers T12 and T13 are used to trigger the Versatile Analog-to-Digital Converter (VADC).

codeExamples.title: CCU6 interrupt generation
codeExamples.name: CCU6_Interrupt_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:
Timer T12 of the CCU6 unit generates an interrupt on a "period match" event every 500 ms.
Inside the ISR, a counter variable is incremented. The LEDs toggle based on the value of the counter:
- LED1 on and LED2 off: counter % 2 == 0
- LED1 off and LED2 on: counter % 2 == 1
codeExamples.abstract: The CCU6 unit generates an interrupt every 500 ms and increments a counter in its Interrupt Service Routine (ISR).

codeExamples.title: CCU6 interrupt generation
codeExamples.name: CCU6_Interrupt_1_KIT_TC297_TFT
codeExamples.description:
Timer T12 of the CCU6  unit generates an interrupt on a "period match" event every 500 ms.
Inside the ISR, a counter variable is incremented.
LEDs toggles based on the value of the counter:
- 1st LED: counter % 4 == 0
- 2nd LED: counter % 4 == 1
- 3rd LED: counter % 4 == 2
- 4th LED: counter % 4 == 3
codeExamples.abstract: The CCU6 unit generates an interrupt every 500 ms and increments a counter in its Interrupt Service Routine (ISR).

codeExamples.title: CCU6 PWM signal capture
codeExamples.name: CCU6_PWM_Capture_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:
A simple PWM signal is generated by toggling a port pin. The resulting PWM frequency and duty cycle
is measured by the Capture/Control Unit 6 (CCU6).
codeExamples.abstract: The CCU6 unit is used to capture an external PWM signal and calculate its frequency and duty cycle.

codeExamples.title: Generation of PWM via CCU6
codeExamples.name: CCU6_PWM_Generation_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:
The code example uses the Timer T12 of CCU6 and its three compare modules to generate three PWM signals
with a frequency of 20 kHz and different duty cycles (25%, 50% and 75%). T12 is configured to count up
and down and the three signals are center aligned. The generated PWM signals are sent to the pins
available on the board and can be observed with an oscilloscope.
codeExamples.abstract: Three center aligned Pulse Width Modulated (PWM) signals with fixed frequency and different duty cycles are generated using CCU6.

codeExamples.title: CPU performance counters
codeExamples.name: CPU_Perf_Counters_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:
The CPU performance counters are counting the number of instructions, clock ticks and multi
counters ticks. They are used to measure the run-time of a c-function.
The result is stored in a global variable.
codeExamples.abstract: Measure code performance via the CPU performance counters

codeExamples.title: TRAP error recognition and reaction
codeExamples.name: CPU_Trap_Recognition_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:
The tutorial describes what types of traps are supported by the AURIX microcontroller, their root
causes and how to identify them. AURIX architecture supports different types of traps. Three different
traps can be provoked with this example and the tutorial guides the user through the needed steps to
observe the root cause of each trap.
codeExamples.abstract: This example shows how to identify the root cause of a trap.

codeExamples.title: DMA transfer of ADC conversion results
codeExamples.name: DMA_ADC_Transfer_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:
At the end of an analog-to-digital conversion of the VADC module, an interrupt is triggered, which starts
the data transfer of the converted ADC results via DMA to the LMURAM. The ADC conversion is started
manually via a command of a serial monitor.
codeExamples.abstract: The DMA is used to transfer ADC measurements results to LMURAM.

codeExamples.title: DMA Linked List Mode usage
codeExamples.name: DMA_Linked_List_Mode_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:
In this training, four DMA transactions are configured in DMA Linked List mode.
Triggering one DMA transaction leads to the execution of all DMA transactions consecutively.
An interrupt is triggered at the completion of the last DMA transaction.
If DMA has correctly transferred the data, the LED driven by port pin 00.6 toggles and a new cycle
starts again. Otherwise, the LED driven by port pin 00.5 turns ON and no more DMA transfers are done.
codeExamples.abstract: DMA Linked Lists are used to execute a series of DMA transactions without CPU intervention.

codeExamples.title: DMA Linked List Mode usage
codeExamples.name: DMA_Linked_List_Mode_1_KIT_TC297_TFT
codeExamples.description:
In this training, four DMA transactions are configured in DMA Linked List mode.
Triggering one DMA transaction leads to the execution of all DMA transactions consecutively.
An interrupt is triggered at the completion of the last DMA transaction.
If DMA has correctly transferred the data, the LED driven by port pin 13.3 toggles and a new cycle
starts again. Otherwise, the LED driven by port pin 13.2 turns ON and no more DMA transfers are done.
codeExamples.abstract: DMA Linked Lists are used to execute a series of DMA transactions without CPU intervention.

codeExamples.title: DMA transfer between memories
codeExamples.name: DMA_Mem_to_Mem_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:
The transfer of data is triggered by SW. The source is the Data Scratch Pad SRAM of CPU0 (DSPR0) and
the destination is the Local Memory Unit (LMURAM). At the end of the transactions, the data is
verified by comparing the source and destination buffers. The success of the data transfer is signaled
through the LED connected to pin 6 of port 00. Otherwise, the LED connected to pin 5 of port 00 is
used. The same cycle is repeated each second.
codeExamples.abstract: The DMA is used to transfer ten words (32-bit) of data from one memory location to another without any CPU load.

codeExamples.title: DMA transfer between memories
codeExamples.name: DMA_Mem_to_Mem_1_KIT_TC297_TFT
codeExamples.description:
The transfer of data is triggered by SW. The source is the Data Scratch Pad SRAM of CPU0 (DSPR0) and
the destination is the Local Memory Unit (LMURAM). At the end of the transactions, the data is
verified by comparing the source and destination buffers. The success of the data transfer is signaled
through the LED connected to pin 0 of port 13. Otherwise, the LED connected to pin 1 of port 13 is
used. The same cycle is repeated each second.
codeExamples.abstract: The DMA is used to transfer ten words (32-bit) of data from one memory location to another without any CPU load.

codeExamples.title: DMA transfer between memories
codeExamples.name: DMA_Mem_to_Mem_1_KIT_TC334_LK
codeExamples.description:
The transfer of data is triggered by SW. The source is the Data Scratch Pad SRAM of CPU0 (DSPR0) and
the destination is the Distributed Local Memory Unit (DLMU RAM). At the end of the transactions,
the data is verified by comparing the source and destination buffers. The success of the data transfer
is signaled through the LED connected to pin 6 of port 00. Otherwise, the LED connected to pin 5 of
port 00 is used. The same cycle is repeated each second.
codeExamples.abstract: The DMA is used to transfer ten words (32-bit) of data from one memory location to another without any CPU load.

codeExamples.title: Delta-Sigma ADC conversion
codeExamples.name: DSADC_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:
The Delta-Sigma ADC (DSADC) continuously measures an external signal on channel 0, connected
to port pin AN2. It converts the analog signal to a data stream and then a global variable is updated
to the current conversion result.
codeExamples.abstract: The DSADC is used to convert an external signal to a stream of discrete digital values.

codeExamples.title: Enhanced Delta-Sigma ADC conversion
codeExamples.name: EDSADC_1_KIT_TC375_LK
codeExamples.description:
The Enhanced Delta-Sigma ADC (EDSADC) continuously measures an external signal on channel 3, connected
to port pin AN0. It converts the analog signal to a data stream and then a global variable is updated
to the current conversion result. The input value is determined by the potentiometer on the board.
codeExamples.abstract: The EDSADC is used to convert an external signal to a stream of discrete digital values.

codeExamples.title: External interrupt generation
codeExamples.name: ERU_Interrupt_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:
The code example uses the External Request Unit (ERU) to generate an interrupt for each
falling and rising edge at an input pin. The falling and rising edges are generated
with the pin P00.7 connected to the board’s button. If an interrupt occurs, an LED will be toggled.
codeExamples.abstract: The ERU is used to generate an interrupt on each rising and falling edge at an input pin.

codeExamples.name: ERU_Interrupt_1_KIT_TC297_TFT
codeExamples.description:

falling and rising edge at the input pin P02.0. The falling and rising edges are generated
with pin P02.1. If an Interrupt occurs, an LED will be toggled.
codeExamples.abstract: The ERU is used to generate an interrupt on each rising and falling edge at an input pin.

codeExamples.title: Ethernet communication
codeExamples.name: Ethernet_1_KIT_TC375_LK
codeExamples.description:
The TCP/IP protocol provided by the Lightweight IP (LwIP) is used to exchange strings between the board
and a remote client terminal.
The board obtains an IP address and publishes its hostname using the DHCP protocol.
The System Timer Module (STM) is used to update the internal LwIP timers.
The Asynchronous/Synchronous Interface (ASCLIN) module is used for debug logging.
codeExamples.abstract: The Gigabit Ethernet Media Access Controller (GETH) module and the Lightweight IP (LwIP) stack are used to implement a network echo application.

codeExamples.title: FCE CRC calculation
codeExamples.name: FCE_CRC_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:
This training shows how to configure the FCE to calculate CRC of a known message
with all supported algorithms (CRC32, CRC16 and CRC8).
The FCE interrupt is enabled to report execution errors.
Any CRC kernel calculation error is indicated by switching ON a different combinations of LEDs.
codeExamples.abstract: The FCE module is used to calculate the CRC of the same message with different algorithms.

codeExamples.title: Flash programming
codeExamples.name: Flash_Programming_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:
In this example, 64 Bytes of the Program Flash memory (PFLASH) are flashed and verified afterwards.
Furthermore, 64 Bytes of the Data Flash memory (DFLASH) are flashed and verified. Before any write
operation, the flash memories are erased. If the flash operation is successful, an LED for each tested
memory is turned ON.
codeExamples.abstract: This example shows how to flash the Program Flash memory and the Data Flash memory.

codeExamples.title: LED controlled via a push button
codeExamples.name: GPIO_LED_Button_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:
Upon pressure of a push button, an LED is turned on and the LED is turned off when releasing the button.
One port pin is configured as input for checking the push button state
and the other port pin is configured as output to control the LED.
codeExamples.abstract: An LED is controlled via a push button.

codeExamples.title: LED controlled via a push button
codeExamples.name: GPIO_LED_Button_1_KIT_TC297_TFT
codeExamples.description:
Upon pressure of a push button, an LED is turned on and the LED is turned off when
releasing the button. One port pin is configured as input for checking the push button
state and the other port pin is configured as output to control the LED.
Short the port pins P14.4 with P14.5 (pin 39 and 40 of header X102) to switch on the LED D110.
codeExamples.abstract: An LED is controlled via a push button.

codeExamples.title: Capture of PWM signal via GPT12
codeExamples.name: GPT12_PWM_Capture_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:
GPT12 timers are configured in capture mode. The data from the captured PWM signal is used to calculate
the PWM frequency in software. The frequency is then stored in a variable.
codeExamples.abstract: The GPT12 unit is used to capture an external PWM signal and calculate the PWM frequency.

codeExamples.title: Generation of PWM via GPT12
codeExamples.name: GPT12_PWM_Generation_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:
The timer T3 of GPT1 is used in timer mode with its count direction configured to "down-counting".
On underflow of timer T3, the Output Toggle Latch (T3OTL) is toggled and the value of timer T2
or T4 is transferred into timer T3 depending on T3OTL value. The state of an LED is toggled in an
interrupt service routine which is triggered by the timer T3.
codeExamples.abstract: A pulse width modulated (PWM) signal with fixed frequency and a defined duty cycle is generated using GPT12.

codeExamples.title: Timer concatenation of GPT12
codeExamples.name: GPT12_Timer_Concatenation_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:
A 32-bit timer is formed by the concatenation of two 16-bit timers of the GPT12 module.
When the 32-bit timer overflows, an interrupt is generated toggling an LED.
codeExamples.abstract: A 32-bit timer is formed by the concatenation of two timers of the GPT12 module. On timer overflow an interrupt is generated, which toggles an LED.

a Real-Time-Clock device mounted on the board KIT_AURIX_TC297_TFT_BC-Step. The AURIX

codeExamples.title: This example shows how to inject an error in CPU0 DSPR memory and run an MBIST to detect it.
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC334_ADS_DSPR_MBIST
codeExamples.description: This example handles the particular case of single core CPU microcontroller and how it's possible to test the CPU0 DSPR while respecting the condition of not accessing the memory during the test.
codeExamples.abstract: This example shows how to inject an error in CPU0 DSPR memory and run an MBIST to detect it.

codeExamples.title: iLLD_TC356TA_ADS_ICMS_BOARD_3_0_point_cloud
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC356TA_ADS_ICMS_BOARD_3_0_point_cloud
codeExamples.description:
This software project is intended as a starting point for the application of in cabin monitoring (ICMS) on the ICMS board v3.0. It demonstrates the main processing steps that need to be performed on AURIX TC356 signal processing unit (SPU) and Tricore CPUs to generate point cloud data from raw data recorded by the BGT60 ATR24AIP MMIC.

Basic understanding of FMCW radar range-doppler signal processing is presumed to follow this code example.
codeExamples.abstract: This software project for the ICMS board v3.0 (AURIX TC356 and BGT60 ATR24AIP) demonstrates the main radar signal processing steps to generate point cloud data from raw data recorded by the MMIC.

codeExamples.title: ICMS RADAR point cloud generation and breathing rate calculation
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC356TA_ICMS_BOARD_3_0_breathing_rate
codeExamples.description:
This software project is intended as a starting point for the application of in cabin monitoring (ICMS) on the ICMS board v3.0. It demonstrates the main processing steps that need to be performed on AURIX TC356 signal processing unit (SPU) and Tricore CPUs to generate point cloud data from raw data recorded by the BGT60 ATR24AIP MMIC and to calculate the breathing rate of a detected target.

Basic understanding of FMCW radar range-doppler signal processing is presumed to follow this code example.
codeExamples.abstract: This software project for the ICMS board v3.0 (AURIX TC356 and BGT60 ATR24AIP) demonstrates the main radar signal processing steps to generate point cloud data from raw data recorded by the MMIC and to calculate the breathing rate of a detected target.

codeExamples.title: Create a random number in the 0 to 255 range using the ADC readings as generator
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC375_ADS_ADC_Random_Number_Generator
codeExamples.description:
The Enhanced Delta-Sigma Analog to Digital Converter (EDSADC) is used to read a value on channel 3, connected to port pin AN0.
The ASCLIN module is configured for UART communication. The Shell from Infineon low level drivers (iLLDs) exploits the Asynchronous/Synchronous Interface (ASCLIN) module to interpret and manage commands from the user like "info", "random" and "help"
which have been developed and are easily expandable. Random command returns a random number between 0 and 255.
Using the EDSADC to select the less significant bit of 8 consecutive readings of the analog channel separated by a predefined wait time helps impoving the quality of the random number. The user restrict the range by predefining the value of n (e.g. random 10 will provide a random number between 0 and 10).
codeExamples.abstract: Create a random number in the 0 to 255 range using the Enhanced Delta-Sigma Analog to Digital Converter (EDSADC) readings as generator

codeExamples.title: LED blinking exploiting C++ Objects
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC375_ADS_Blinky_LED_CPP
codeExamples.description:
This project is a simple example of how C++ objects can be used in AURIX(TM) projects.
In this example, an LED object is used to control the port pins of the two LEDs on the AURIX(TM) TC375 Lite Kit.
This example can be used as a template for creating and using methods in C++ for AURIX(TM).
codeExamples.abstract: Two LEDs are turned on and off exploiting C++ Objects

codeExamples.title: Bluetooth application firmware download and execution
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC375_ADS_Bluetooth_RFCOMM
codeExamples.description:
The example enables the extension of AURIX(TM) devices with the BLE (Bluetooth Low Energy) and classic
bluetooth capability which is provided by Infineon's CYW20819 device. The application firmware binary
which is distributed within this example implements a RFCOMM (Radio Frequency Communication) bluetooth
classic profile for the CYW20819 device. This application binary is downloaded by AURIX(TM) to the
CYW20819 device. During execution of the application binary, the data received/transmitted on the
RFCOMM bluetooth interface by the CYW20819 device is bridged to a UART (Universal Asynchronous
Receiver Transmitter), which is connected to AURIX(TM) and processed on AURIX(TM) within a shell. A shell
is a user interface for parsing commands and accessing services. By this, a RFCOMM bluetooth
application on a remote device (i.e. smartphone) can be used as a terminal application to communicate
with AURIX(TM).
codeExamples.abstract: Demonstrate the download of an application firmware to Infineon's CYW20819 device family by applying the AIROC(TM) HCI UART Control Protocol on AURIX(TM)

codeExamples.title: iLLD_TC375_ADS_BUS_Memory_Protection_LiteKit
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC375_ADS_BUS_Memory_Protection_LiteKit
codeExamples.description:
The BUS Memory Protection Unit (BUS MPU) is focused on 2 CPUs (CPU0, CPU1), and handles â€œread/writeâ€? access permission to
the local memory of CPU0 (DSPR0/PSPR0/DLMU0/Pflash0) from the bus master CPU1.
In this code example the BUS master CPU0 has always â€œread/writeâ€? permission of local memory of CPU0, while
bus master CPU1 does not have access permission to that area. Different test scenarios has been provided to
define access permission for each local memories.
codeExamples.abstract: CPU0 and CPU1 are handles read/write access permission to the local memory of CPU0 from the bus master CPU1.

codeExamples.title: Read the data from DHT11 and visualize it using OneEye GUI
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC375_ADS_DHT11
codeExamples.description: This project is a simple example of how to read the data from the temperature/humidity sensor DHT11 and visualize it using OneEye
codeExamples.abstract: This project is a simple example of how to read the data from the temperature/humidity sensor DHT11 and visualize it using OneEye

codeExamples.title: Example of EVADC Master Slave configuration for synchronous sampling of slave channels with master channel
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC375_ADS_EVADC_Master_Slave_GTM_ATOM_Trig
codeExamples.description:
To whom this example is useful?
When multiple ADC inputs are to be sampled simultaneously, then normally the same trigger signal is used. It is possible that such trigger signal is not connected to all EVADC queues. This example is useful for such use-cases, where some of the EVADC queues are not connected to the same HW trigger.
With this example, three EVADC channels sample the analog input synchronously at the same time. Here the different groups are configured with master slave configuration, where only the master is triggered by GTM output.
codeExamples.abstract: Example of EVADC Master Slave configuration for synchronous sampling of slave channels with master channel

codeExamples.title: Compute the FFT transform on a buffer of ADC readings
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC375_ADS_FFT_Frequency_Analyzer_Microphone
codeExamples.description:
This code example explains how to connect a microphone type KY-038 to the evaluation board, to collect analog sample and to apply a FFT to the data collected.
The microphone type KY-038 is connected to the board with GND, 3.3 V and Analog Out pins.
Capture/Compare Unit 6 (CCU6) is used to generate a timed interrupt.
The Enhanced Versatile Analog-to-Digital Converter (EVADC) group 0 is used to read a value on channel 1. This channel is connected to port pin AN1. The reading is performed by the interrupt routine triggered by CCU6.
Each analog reading is stored in a buffer, once it is filled, a flag is set and the FFT is performed.
codeExamples.abstract: CPU0 sets the analog input channel and reads the output of a microphone using CCU6 generated interrupts. Once the buffer is filled CPU1 computes the Fast Fourier Transform (FFT).

codeExamples.title: Inject an ECC error into Program and Data Flash
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC375_ADS_Flash_ECC_Error_Injection
codeExamples.description: Inject an ECC error in one of the valid pages of the PFlash and DFlash
codeExamples.abstract: Inject an ECC (Error Correction Code) error into the Program or Data Flash

codeExamples.description: This example explores FreeRTOS usage on AURIX(TM) TC375 using two simple tasks and one interrupt
codeExamples.abstract: This example shows how to get started with using the AURIX(TM) FreeRTOS port

codeExamples.title: Gpt12 incremental encoder
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC375_ADS_GPT12_Incremental_Encoder_1
codeExamples.description: The incremental encoder signals are emulated using GPIOs. Those signals are connected to GPT12 timer T3 and timer T4 inputs. Timer T3 capture encoder A and B signals, while timer T4 is used to capture encoder index signal.
codeExamples.abstract: The GPT12 is configured to support incremental encoder. The incremental encoder signals are emulated using GPIOs.

codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC375_ADS_GTM_ATOM_CLLC_Converter_PWM_1
codeExamples.description:
This example is intended to show, how to configure the iLLD framework (GTM ATOM) to generate PWM signals
for CLLC DC-DC converter.
The states of the 8 pins are controlled by the PWM signals generated by the Generic Timer Module (GTM)
in-built ARU-Connected Timer Output Module (ATOM). All signals are synchronous to each other, edge aligned,
phase shifted and with dead times (positive/negative) for the complementary pairs.
codeExamples.abstract: The GTM ATOM is configured to generate a PWM signals for CLLC DC-DC converter.

codeExamples.abstract: The GTM ATOM is configured to generate a PWM signals for Dual Active Bridge (DAB) converter.

codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC375_ADS_JSON_Parse_To_Serial
codeExamples.description:
A JSON document with nested documents, saved in a global variable, is parsed and the values of its fields
are printed to the serial terminal in another format.
codeExamples.abstract: A JavaScript Object Notation (JSON) document is parsed and the result is sent to the serial terminal.

codeExamples.title: Control 2 leds with one button.
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC375_ADS_LED_DoubleClick_Button
codeExamples.description:
The state of LED1 and LED2 is controlled by one button, so it is necessary to be able to detect when it is pressed once or twice.
When the button is pressed, a 300ms timer starts to detect the double click.
When the timer has expired, the state of the corresponding LED will changes according to the number of times the button has been pressed.
codeExamples.abstract: LED1 and LED2 are controlled by a single button. A single click toggles the state of LED1, a double click toggles the state of LED2.

codeExamples.title: iLLD_TC375_ADS_LVGL_Code_Example_1
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC375_ADS_LVGL_Code_Example_1
codeExamples.description: This project is a simple example of how a TFT Touch display in combination with the LVGL library can be used in AURIX(TM) projects.
codeExamples.abstract: This project is a simple example of how a Thin Film Transistor (TFT) Touch display in combination with the Light and Versatile Graphics Library library (LVGL) can be used in AURIX(TM) projects.

codeExamples.title: MQTT client example for the TC375 LiteKit
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC375_ADS_MQTT_Client_1
codeExamples.description:
The AURIX(TM) TC375 Gigabit Ethernet (GETH) is used to run the lwIP open source TCP/IP stack. The
MQTT client example runs on top of the lwIP MQTT "application". The client subscribes to "IO/LED1"
and "IO/LED2" topics, which allow controlling the states of LED1 and LED2 on the TC375 LiteKit via
MQTT messages, "ON" or "OFF", published to these topics. If BUTTON1 is pressed, the client publishes
an empty message to the "IO/BTN1" topic to indicate that the button was pressed.
codeExamples.abstract: MQTT client example using the lwIP open source TCP/IP stack

codeExamples.title: iLLD_TC375_ADS_OVERLAY_LITEKIT
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC375_ADS_OVERLAY_LITEKIT
codeExamples.description: The data overlay functionality provides the possibility of redirecting data read access from a non-volatile
codeExamples.abstract: The data access overlay (OVC) provides the capability to redirect selected data accesses to the Overlay memory.

codeExamples.title: iLLD TC375 ADS printf scanf
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC375_ADS_printf_scanf
codeExamples.description: The printf/scanf functions are retargeted for TASKING/GCC compilers to send/read data via ASCLIN in ASC (UART) mode.
codeExamples.abstract: The printf/scanf functions are used to send/read data with ASCLIN.

codeExamples.title: iLLD_TC375_ADS_PSI5_SensorEmulator
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC375_ADS_PSI5_SensorEmulator
codeExamples.description: This project is a simple example of how to emulate the sensor data (Manchester encoded) using SPI MOSI and this encoded data is provided as an input to PSI5 interface.
codeExamples.abstract: This project is an example of how to emulate a Manchester encoder using SPI and provide this as an input to the PSI interface

codeExamples.title: QSPI Safe Communication
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC375_ADS_QSPI_SAFE_COMMUNICATION
codeExamples.description:
The code example explains how to ensure the safety and integrity of data transmitted through Queued
Synchronous Peripheral Interface (QSPI)
codeExamples.abstract: The example code is about the implementation of QSPI safe communication safety mechanism

codeExamples.title: iLLD_TC375_ADS_REDUNDANT_ADC_STM_SMU
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC375_ADS_REDUNDANT_ADC_STM_SMU
codeExamples.description: This project uses a EVADC channel and a DSADC channel to periodically sense the voltage at the output of a potentiometer, using STM (System Timer) to trigger the conversions. The difference between the two voltages is then saved in an array where the mean value is calculated. Whenever the mean value of the differences array is over a certain treshold an alarm is activated and an interrupt is triggered as reaction from SMU (Safety Management Unit). The interrupt routine in turn activates one of the LEDs on the board. The voltages sensed by the ADCs are also printed into the Console using UART.
codeExamples.abstract: A VADC and a DSADC channel read analog values out of the embedded potentiometer. When the mean value of the difference bewteen the two ADCs samples is over a certain threshold, an alarm is activated

codeExamples.title: Safe application development for AURIX(TM) TC375 safety lite kit
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC375_ADS_SAFETY_LITE_KIT
codeExamples.description:
This project is written for system and software engineers and functional safety managers
involved in the design or development of a safety-related system who are considering
integrating the AURIX(TM) TC3xx micro-controller hardware as a safety element out of
context (SEooC) into their system.
codeExamples.abstract: This source code is an easy step to start and understand the functional safety aspects

codeExamples.title: iLLD_TC375_ADS_SCR_RTC_70kHz_trimming_LK
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC375_ADS_SCR_RTC_70kHz_trimming_LK
codeExamples.description:
This is a minimal code example presenting a solution to application scenario 3 from Application Note AP32465.
The goal is to periodically trim the low power 70kHz low frequency (LF) oscillator. This oscillator is specially for low power application but naturally very imprecise and usually used by the Wake-up Timer (WUT) and Standby Controller (SCR) Real-Time Clock (RTC) timers.
Using the WUT and the Capture/Compare Unit 6 (CCU6) a calibration coefficient is calculated and transferred to the SCR domain.
codeExamples.abstract: This code example demonstrates Standby Controller Real-Time Clock calibration using Wake-up Timer and Capture-Compare Unit.

codeExamples.title: iLLD_TC375_ADS_SCR_RTC_ADCOMP_wakeup_LK
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC375_ADS_SCR_RTC_ADCOMP_wakeup_LK
codeExamples.description:
This is a minimal code example presenting a solution to application scenario 2 from Application Note AP32465.
The goal is to perform a periodic evaluation of a few analog channels and trigger a wake-up if threshold crossing is detected.
High ADC resolution is not required (LSB = 25 mV or better) in this mode.
codeExamples.abstract: This code example demonstrates periodic ADC (Analog Digital Converter) measurement in standby mode using SCR (Standby Controller).

codeExamples.title: iLLD_TC375_ADS_SCR_RTC_periodic-wakeup_LK
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC375_ADS_SCR_RTC_periodic-wakeup_LK
codeExamples.description:
This is a minimal code example presenting a solution to application scenario 1 from Application Note AP32465.
The goal is to periodically monitor I/O lines for logic level change in standby mode and wake-up the TriCore(TM) Cpu to perform communication with external components (e.g. via LIN channels).
The TriCore(TM) CPU is used to mirror the port line P33.4 to P00.5 which has LED1 connected on the AURIX(TM) TC375 lite Kit V2.
codeExamples.abstract: This code example demonstrates periodic pin monitoring in standby mode using SCR (Standby Controller).

codeExamples.title: iLLD_TC375_ADS_SCR_SPI-32bit-controller_LK
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC375_ADS_SCR_SPI-32bit-controller_LK
codeExamples.description:
This code example gives an overview how to configure the SCR SSC module as SPI master device and transfer 32-bit data from/to a slave device.
The configuration is encapsulated in the files `spi.h` and `spi.c` and provides all possible configurations for all available MOSI, MISO and SCLK lines.
The optional CS lines are limited to a subset of four available pins.
codeExamples.abstract: This repository is an SCR example demonstrating the SCR-SPI initialization and SW for an 32-bit SPI controller (master).

codeExamples.title: iLLD_TC375_ADS_SCR_SPI-8bit-controller_LK
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC375_ADS_SCR_SPI-8bit-controller_LK
codeExamples.description:
This code example gives an overview how to configure the SCR SSC module as SPI master device and transfer 8-bit data from/to a slave device.
The configuration is encapsulated in the files `spi.h` and `spi.c` and provides all possible configurations for all available MOSI, MISO and SCLK lines.
The optional CS lines are limited to a subset of four available pins.
codeExamples.abstract: This repository is an SCR example demonstrating the SCR-SPI initialization for an 8-bit SPI controller (master).

codeExamples.title: Example of simple SENT communication to interface TLE5014 GMR angle sensor with AURIX(TM) TC3x Device.
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC375_ADS_TLE5014_Interface_SENT_Simple
codeExamples.description: With this example, SENT interfacing using AURIX(TM) TC3x Device with TLE5014 angle sensor is demonstrated.
codeExamples.abstract: Example of simple SENT communication to interface TLE5014 GMR angle sensor.

codeExamples.title: iLLD_TC377TP_ADS_LWIP-HTTP-Server
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC377TP_ADS_LWIP-HTTP-Server
codeExamples.description:
The die temperature is read from an HTTP server implemented in the LWIP 2.2.0 stack. LED manipulation is done via the HTTP server.
A CAN node and a LIN master node are also implemented. The CAN implementation can be configured to be used in loop-back mode or with an external CAN node. The LIN implementation configures a LIN Master node that sends a header and a data block on the LIN bus.
The MCU's IEEE 1588 capabilities are also enabled.
codeExamples.abstract: This code example demonstrates the TC377 peripheral capabilities by implementing a CAN and LIN node together with an HTTP server using the LWIP 2.2.0 stack. The server reads the die temperature and it can manipulate LEDs. Also, this code example demonstrates how to enable the MCU's IEEE 1588 capabilities.

codeExamples.title: iLLD_TC377TX_ADS_LWIP-HTTP-Server
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC377TX_ADS_LWIP-HTTP-Server
codeExamples.description: The die temperature is read from an HTTP server implemented in the LWIP 2.2.0 stack. LED manipulation is done via the HTTP server. A CAN node and a LIN master node are also implemented. The CAN implementation can be configured to be used in loop-back mode or with an external CAN node. The LIN implementation configures a LIN Master node that sends a header and a data block on the LIN bus.
codeExamples.abstract: This code example demonstrates the TC377 peripheral capabilities by implementing a CAN and LIN node together with an HTTP server using the LWIP 2.2.0 stack. The server reads the die temperature and it can manipulate LEDs.

codeExamples.title: This code example generates a periodic interrupt using the SCR RTC Module.
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC37x_ADS_SCR_Blinky_LED_LK_1
codeExamples.description: This is a simple SCR (Standby Controller) example code using LED1 on the TC375 lite Kit to show a successfully working code. The SCR RTC (Real-Time Clock) module is used to generate a periodic interrupt to toggle the port SCR_P00.4 (P33.4) output. The TriCore(TM) CPU is used to mirror the port line P33.4 to P00.5 which has LED1 connected on the TC375 lite Kit.
codeExamples.abstract: This code example generates a periodic interrupt using the SCR RTC Module.

codeExamples.title: GTM ATOM 3-Phase Inverter PWM generation
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC387_ADS_GTM_ATOM_3_Phase_Inverter_PWM_1
codeExamples.description:
The states of the 6 pins are controlled by the PWM signals generated by the Generic Timer
Module (GTM) in-built ARU-Connected Timer Output Module (ATOM). All signals are synchronous to each
other, center-aligned and with dead-times (positive/negative) for the complementary pairs.
codeExamples.abstract: The GTM ATOM is configured to generate a PWM signals for two-level three phase inverter.

codeExamples.title: CLLC DC-DC PWM Generation
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC387_ADS_GTM_ATOM_CLLC_Converter_PWM_1
codeExamples.description:
This example is intended to show, how to configure the iLLD framework (GTM ATOM) to generate PWM signals
for CLLC DC-DC converter.
The states of the 8 pins are controlled by the PWM signals generated by the Generic Timer Module (GTM)
in-built ARU-Connected Timer Output Module (ATOM). All signals are synchronous to each other, edge aligned,
phase shifted and with dead times (positive/negative) for the complementary pairs.
codeExamples.abstract: The GTM ATOM is configured to generate a PWM signals for CLLC DC-DC converter.

codeExamples.title: GTM TOM 3-Phase Inverter PWM generation
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC387_ADS_GTM_TOM_3_Phase_Inverter_PWM_1
codeExamples.description:
The states of the 6 pins are controlled by the PWM signals generated by the Generic Timer
Module (GTM) in-built Timer Output Module (TOM). All signals are synchronous to each
other, center-aligned and with dead-times (positive/negative) for the complementary pairs.
codeExamples.abstract: The GTM TOM is configured to generate a PWM signals for two-level three phase inverter.

codeExamples.title: Signal Processing Unit basic configuration
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC397X_ADS_SPU_Basics
codeExamples.description:
This project shows a basic radar data processing flow implemented on the Signal Processing Unit (SPU)
hardware. The processing flow includes range-doppler processing of a raw data cube and subsequent target detection
using CFAR. This code example uses a simulated dataset as input, Radar interface (RIF) configuration is not shown.
Basic understanding of FMCW radar range-doppler signal processing is presumed to follow this code example.
codeExamples.abstract: This code example shows the basic usage of the Signal Processing Unit (SPU), implementing a basic radar data processing flow.

codeExamples.title: Signal Processing Unit configuration for clutter removal
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC397x_ADS_SPU_Clutter_Removal
codeExamples.description:
This project shows a basic radar data processing flow for clutter suppression implemented on the Signal Processing Unit (SPU) hardware. Clutter suppression is used to remove static targets from the dataset. The processing flow includes clutter removal on the range FFT data cube and doppler FFT both on a range map with and without clutter. This code example uses a simulated dataset as input, Radar interface (RIF) configuration is not shown.

Basic understanding of FMCW radar range-doppler signal processing is presumed to follow this code example.
codeExamples.abstract: This code example illustrates the configuration of the Signal Processing Unit (SPU) for implementing clutter suppression, a standard step in radar data processing for in cabin monitoring systems (ICMS).

codeExamples.title: SDCard multiblock Read Write with SDMMC_
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC397_3V3_ADS_SDCard_SDMMC_Read_Write
codeExamples.description:
The SDMMC is initialized in 4 bit configuration with SDMA mode.
Using the FatFs file system the SDCard is mounted and a message is written into text file "Message.txt" (the file is created if inexistent).
The text file is then read and the message is displayed on the serial terminal.
codeExamples.abstract: Write and read a text file in an SD_Card connected to the SDMMC peripheral.

codeExamples.title: iLLD_TC397_ADS_CAN_Gateway_ISR
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC397_ADS_CAN_Gateway_ISR
codeExamples.description:
Some applications require an automatic CAN frames re-routing between two different CAN busses without CPU interaction.
Such a "gateway" feature is not available in MCMCAN module of TC3xx family devices.
This example shows how to implement a "SW gatewayâ€œ for routing CAN frame by using the ISR (Interrupt service routine).

CAN0 (CAN0 node0) is configured as "gateway source" and CAN1 (CAN1 node0) as "gateway destination".
The defined messages restored in the RxFIFO on the "gateway source" will be rerouted to "gateway destination" by using the ISR.
In order to avoid message losing due to CPU latency the RxFIFO is configured on the source node; while TxFIFO is configured on
the destination node in order to avoid delayed transmission due to higher load on the destination bus.
codeExamples.abstract: This example shows how to use the ISR for routing CAN frame received on one bus to another bus

codeExamples.title: Clock Plausibility
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC397_ADS_ESM_SW_CLOCK_PLAUSIBILITY
codeExamples.description:
The scope of this project is to understand how to implement a software based clock plausibility
ESM (External Safety Mechanism). Application Software (SW) shall evaluate the different clock frequencies
provided by Peripheral PLL Configuration 1 register (PERPLLCON1.K2, PERPLLCON1.K3) with a time measurement
based on System PLL Configuration 1 register (SYSPLLCON1.K2) clock frequency, where K2 and K3 are divider
values. If the measured and expected clock frequency values does not match, the application SW shall
trigger an alarm.
codeExamples.abstract: This code example presents the implementation of software based Clock Plausibility.

codeExamples.title: Port loopback safety mechanism
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC397_ADS_PORT_LOOPBACK
codeExamples.description:
The scope of this project is to understand how to implement a software based Port loopback
Safety Mechanism (SM). The application Software (SW) shall configure and use redundant General Purpose
Input Output (GPIO) to detect faults when receiving or transmitting the information.
codeExamples.abstract: This code example presents the implementation of port loopback safety mechanism

codeExamples.title: Port redundancy safety mechanism
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC397_ADS_PORT_REDUNDANCY
codeExamples.description:
The scope of this code example is to understand how to implement a software based port redundancy
safety mechanism (SM). The application software (SW) shall configure and use redundant General Purpose
Input Output (GPIO) to detect faults when receiving or transmitting the information.
codeExamples.abstract: This code example presents the implementation of port redundancy safety mechanism

codeExamples.title: Read from SD card and print to serial terminal
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC397_ADS_SD_Read_To_Serial
codeExamples.description:
A text file is read from a SD card using the Queued Serial Peripheral Interface (QSPI) protocol and the FatFS library.
The text taken from the file is the sent to the serial terminal.
codeExamples.abstract: A text file is read from an Secure Digital (SD) card and its content is printed to the serial terminal.

codeExamples.title: SENT Redundancy
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC397_ADS_SENT_Redundancy_SPC_Trig_TLE5012_GTM_TOM
codeExamples.description:
This example demonstrates the Short PWM Code (SPC) protocol by interfacing an AURIX (TM) TC3xx Device
as master with a TLE5012 angle sensor as slave. The SPC pulse which needs to be sent by the master to
the slave is periodically triggered on each rising edge of a PWM signal generated by the Generic Timer
Module (GTM) using the Timer Output Module (TOM).
codeExamples.abstract: Example of SENT SPC communication to interface TLE5012 GMR angle sensor.

codeExamples.title: iLLD_TC397_APPKIT_5V_ADS_PMIC_SLEEP_MODE
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC397_APPKIT_5V_ADS_PMIC_SLEEP_MODE
codeExamples.description: This code example uses the Queued Synchronous Peripheral Interface (QSPI) and the Asynchronous/Synchronous Interface (ASCLIN) module to communicate with the on board PMIC and put the board in sleep mode. The CPU communicates with the PMIC via QSPI, an ASCLIN interrupt triggers the PMIC state transition to sleep or normal mode.
codeExamples.abstract: This code example send a request to put the Power Management IC (PMIC) TLF35584 in Sleep mode or Normal mode.

codeExamples.title: iLLD_TC397_APPKIT_5V_ADS_PMIC_STANDBY_MODE
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC397_APPKIT_5V_ADS_PMIC_STANDBY_MODE
codeExamples.description: This code example uses the Queued Synchronous Peripheral Interface (QSPI) and the Asynchronous/Synchronous Interface (ASCLIN) module to communicate with the on board PMIC and put the board in Standby mode. The CPU communicates with the PMIC via QSPI, an ASCLIN interrupt triggers the PMIC state transition to standby, then the board directly transits into standby mode.
codeExamples.abstract: This code example send a request to put the board in STANDBY mode with the Power Management IC (PMIC).

codeExamples.title: iLLD_tc397_APPKIT_5V_ADS_TLE4973_Current_Sensor
codeExamples.name: iLLD_tc397_APPKIT_5V_ADS_TLE4973_Current_Sensor
codeExamples.description: This code example uses the UART interface of the microcontroller to interact with 3 TLE4973 sensors (TLE4973 evaluation board). It offers the choice to the user to measure the current of one the 3 sensors of the evaluation board.
codeExamples.abstract: This code example provides a user interface for current measurement using the TLE4973 EVALUATION BOARD

codeExamples.title: iLLD_TC397_TFT_ADS_LMU_Memory_Protection
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC397_TFT_ADS_LMU_Memory_Protection
codeExamples.description:
The LMU Memory Protection Unit (LMU MPU) is focused on 2 CPUs (CPU0, CPU1), and handles read/write
access permission to LMU0 from the bus master CPU0 and CPU1.
In this code example the BUS master CPU0 has always read/write permission of LMU0, while bus master
CPU1 does not have access permission to that area.
Different test scenarios has been provided to define access permission for LMU0.
codeExamples.abstract: CPU0 and CPU1 are handles read/write access permission to LMU0 from the bus master CPU0 and CPU1.

codeExamples.title: iLLD_TC397_TRIBOARD_ADS_PMIC_SLEEP_MODE
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC397_TRIBOARD_ADS_PMIC_SLEEP_MODE
codeExamples.description: This code example uses the Queued Synchronous Peripheral Interface (QSPI) and the Asynchronous/Synchronous Interface (ASCLIN) module to communicate with the on board PMIC and put the board in sleep mode. The CPU communicates with the PMIC via QSPI, an ASCLIN interrupt triggers the PMIC state transition to sleep or normal mode.
codeExamples.abstract: This code example send a request to put the Power Management IC (PMIC) TLF35584 in Sleep mode or Normal mode.

codeExamples.title: iLLD_TC397_TRIBOARD_ADS_PMIC_STANDBY_MODE
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC397_TRIBOARD_ADS_PMIC_STANDBY_MODE
codeExamples.description: This code example uses the Queued Synchronous Peripheral Interface (QSPI) and the Asynchronous/Synchronous Interface (ASCLIN) module to communicate with the on board PMIC and put the board in standby mode, the wake-up is done by the Standby Controller (SCR). The CPU communicates with the PMIC via QSPI, an ASCLIN interrupt triggers the PMIC state transition to standby, then the board directly transits into standby mode.
codeExamples.abstract: This code example send a request to put the board and STANDBY mode with the Power Management IC (PMIC).

codeExamples.title: Safe Application Development for AURIX(TM) Application kit TC3xx Safety
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC39B_ADS_SAFETY_KIT
codeExamples.description:
This project is written for system and software engineers and functional safety managers involved in
the design or development of a safety-related system who are considering integrating the AURIX(TM)
TC3xx micro-controller hardware as a safety element out of context (SEooC) into their system.
codeExamples.abstract: This source code is the first and easy step to start and understand the functional safety aspects

codeExamples.title: Compute CRC over a memory range in PFLASH using DMA
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC3XX_ADS_DMA_CRC32
codeExamples.description:
The Direct Memory Access module (DMA) calculates CRC of transferred data during a transfer.
The memory range in Program Flash (PFLASH) over which CRC has to be calculate is set as the data source in a DMA transfer and destination as any location in RAM.
After the DMA transfer is complete the CRC is read from the DMA module.
This CRC is compared against the CRC calculated using the CPU CRC32 instruction over the same memory range in PFLASH.
Different LEDs are tunred on depending upon if the CPU and DMA calculated CRCs match or not.
codeExamples.abstract: Compute CRC over a memory range in PFLASH using DMA

codeExamples.title: The Gigabit Ethernet is used to run an open source TCP/IP stack with an HTTP Server toggling LEDs and visualizing the temperature of the device read from the Die Temperature Sensor (DTS)
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC3XX_ADS_GETH_LWIP_HTTP
codeExamples.description:
The internal Die Temperature Sensor (DTS) is continuously read in an infinite loop.
The measure is converted in Celsius and visualized in the Lightweight IP (LWIP) HTTP server.
In addition the webserver provides 2 buttons to turn a Lite Kit LED ON and OFF.
codeExamples.abstract: The Gigabit Ethernet is used to run an open source TCP/IP stack with an HTTP Server toggling LEDs and visualizing the temperature of the device read from the Die Temperature Sensor (DTS)

codeExamples.title: RD-Map to radar target range and velocity conversion
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC3XX_ADS_RDmap_conversion
codeExamples.description: Two pre-computed detection bitmaps (results of local maximum searches of a NCI range-doppler map in range and doppler dimension) are combined bitwise and the range and velocity of the detected targets are calculated and stored.
codeExamples.abstract: This example shows how to combine two radar detection bitmaps and how to convert the index of a radar target in the range-doppler map to target distance and velocity.

codeExamples.title: Checks if a given address sector in Program Flash is erased
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC3XX_ADS_Verify_PFlash_Erase
codeExamples.description:
A sector in Program Flash (PFLASH) is erased. The erasure verification service is invoked and the DMU_HF_ERRSR.EVER register bitfield is examined.
The same sector is then programmed with data. The erasure verification service is invoked and the DMU_HF_ERRSR.EVER register bitfield is examined.
codeExamples.abstract: Checks if a given address sector in Program Flash is erased

codeExamples.title: iLLD_TC4D7_LITE_KIT_ADS_ETH_DEMO
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC4D7_lite_kit_ADS_ETH_Demo
codeExamples.description: This code example implements an ethernet echo server replying to Layer 2 packets. The demo configures GETH module using DMA Channel 0 and Tx/Rx Queues 0.
codeExamples.abstract: This code example implements an ethernet echo server (raw Ethernet) using GETH port 0.

codeExamples.title: TMADC CDSP Filtering with Interrupts
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC4D7_LK_ADC_CDSP_TMADC_Filtering
codeExamples.description:
An amplitude modulated sine wave is fed to the Time-Multiplexed ADC (TMADC) as input.
The Converter Digital Signal Processor (CDSP) as a FIR filter removes high frequency harmonics from the
TMADC output signal. TMADC output is fed as input to the CDSP. During their respective service request
events, the CDSP and TMADC outputs are stored in an array and traced.
codeExamples.abstract: The CDSP filters out high frequency components of the signal sampled by TMADC

codeExamples.title: LIN master communication via ASCLIN module
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC4D7_LK_ADS_ASCLIN_LIN_Send
codeExamples.description:
The string "Hello!" is sent via an ASCLIN module configured as LIN master.
The signal can be visualized using an oscilloscope.
codeExamples.abstract: An ASCLIN module is configured as LIN master to send "Hello!"

codeExamples.title: Shell via UART communication
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC4D7_LK_ADS_ASCLIN_Shell_UART
codeExamples.description:
The ASCLIN module is configured for UART communication.
The Shell from iLLDs exploits the ASCLIN module to interpret and manage commands from the
user like "info", "toggle [x]" or "help".
codeExamples.abstract: Shell is used to parse a command line and call the corresponding command execution. The ASCLIN module is used to interface with the Shell through the USB port via UART.

codeExamples.title: SPI master communication via ASCLIN module
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC4D7_LK_ADS_ASCLIN_SPI_Master
codeExamples.description:
An ASCLIN module configured as SPI master sends a two byte message.
The two byte message is sent through MTSR (MOSI) port pin P15.4 with SCLK on port P20.10 in loopback
mode. This signal can be visualized on the oscilloscope screen.
codeExamples.abstract: An ASCLIN module configured as SPI master sends a two byte message.

codeExamples.title: UART communication via ASCLIN module
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC4D7_LK_ADS_ASCLIN_UART
codeExamples.description:
The string "Hello World!" is sent and received via UART through one pin due to the internal loopback.
The data can be visualized using an oscilloscope.
codeExamples.abstract: An ASCLIN module configured for UART communication sends "Hello World!" and receives the string back via the internal loopback.

codeExamples.title: Assembly language in C code
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC4D7_LK_ADS_Assembly_C_Code
codeExamples.description: Two LEDs are switched on then switched off using assembly code functions.
codeExamples.abstract: Inline assembler and assembler files are used in combination in a C project.

codeExamples.title: Blinky LED
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC4D7_LK_ADS_Blinky_LED
codeExamples.description: A wait function is used to add delays between switching on and switching off an LED on port pin P03.9
codeExamples.abstract: An LED is blinking based on the timing given by a wait function.

codeExamples.title: CPU_Perf_Counters
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC4D7_LK_ADS_CPU_Perf_Counters
codeExamples.description:
The CPU performance counters are counting the number of instructions, clock ticks and multi counters ticks.
They are used to measure the run-time of a c-function. The result is stored in a global variable.
codeExamples.abstract: Measure code performance via the CPU performance counters

codeExamples.title: Trap error recognition and reaction
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC4D7_LK_ADS_CPU_Trap_Recognition
codeExamples.description:
The tutorial describes what types of traps are supported by the AURIX (TM)
microcontroller, their root causes and how to identify them. AURIX (TM)
architecture supports different types of traps. Three different traps can be
provoked with this example and the tutorial guides the user through the
needed steps to observe the root cause of each trap.
codeExamples.abstract: This example shows how to identify the root cause of a trap.

codeExamples.title: DMA Linked List Mode usage
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC4D7_LK_ADS_DMA_Linked_List_Mode
codeExamples.description:
In this example, four DMA transactions are configured in DMA Linked List mode.
Triggering one DMA transaction leads to the execution of all DMA transactions consecutively.
An interrupt is triggered at the completion of the last DMA transaction.
If DMA has correctly transferred the data, the LED 1 driven by port pin 03.9 toggles and a new cycle
starts again. Otherwise, the LED 2 driven by port pin 03.10 turns ON and no more DMA transfers are done.
codeExamples.abstract: DMA Linked Lists are used to execute a series of DMA transactions without CPU intervention.

codeExamples.title: EGTM PWM input capturing via TIM
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC4D7_LK_ADS_EGTM_TIM_Capture
codeExamples.description:
The Timer Input Module (TIM) of the Enhanced Generic Timer Module (EGTM) is used in capture mode.
The data from the captured PWM signal is used to calculate the PWM signal frequency and duty cycle in software.
The frequency and the duty cycle are then stored in variables.
codeExamples.abstract: A timer is used to capture an external PWM signal and calculate the PWM signal frequency and duty cycle.

codeExamples.title: EGTM TOM PWM generation
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC4D7_LK_ADS_EGTM_TOM_PWM
codeExamples.description:
The LED 1 is driven by pin 9 of the port 3. The state of the pin is controlled by the PWM signal generated
by the Enhanced Generic Timer Module (EGTM) in-built Timer Output Module (TOM).
codeExamples.abstract: EGTM TOM is used to generate a PWM signal, which is driving the intensity of an LED.

codeExamples.title: Flash Programming
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC4D7_LK_ADS_Flash_Programming
codeExamples.description: Simple example showing the needed steps for Pflash and Dflash erase and programming operations.
codeExamples.abstract: This example shows how to erase, program, and run a verify loop on the PFlash and the DFlash memories of the TC4Dx.

codeExamples.title: LED controlled via a push button
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC4D7_LK_ADS_GPIO_LED_Button
codeExamples.description:
Upon pressure of a push button, an LED is turned on and the LED is turned off when
releasing the button. One port pin is configured as input for checking the push button
state and the other port pin is configured as output to control the LED.
codeExamples.abstract: An LED is controlled via a push button.

codeExamples.title: I2C_Read_Ext_Device
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC4D7_LK_ADS_I2C_Read_Ext_Device
codeExamples.description: An I2C module configured as I2C master is used to read the MAC address stored in the Microchip 2K I2C Serial EEPROM mounted on the board KIT_A3G_TC4D7_LITE. The AURIX™ device reads the MAC address through the I2C module and stores it into a global variable.
codeExamples.abstract: An I2C module configured as I2C master is used to read a register of an external device.

codeExamples.title: Interrupt Priority
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC4D7_LK_ADS_Interrupt_Prio
codeExamples.description: On Core 0, two STM interrupts are configured to control the state of two LEDs (P03.9 & P03.10) along with incrementing respective ISRs counters and third interrupt is being generated by Core1 STM to Core 0 which only incrementing respective ISR counter. Based on their priority, the interrupts toggle the appropriate LED and increment counters. In this example, the interrupts are triggered by STM module.
codeExamples.abstract: Three interrupts with different priorities are used to toggle available two LEDs and incrementing respective ISRs counters.

codeExamples.title: illd_tc4d7_lk_ads_mpu_memory_protection
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC4D7_LK_ADS_MPU_Memory_Protection
codeExamples.description:
The MPU module is configured to enable the first half and protect the second half of an array from read/write accesses.
To test the function of the read protection, each element of the array is read in a loop.
Two LEDs are used to indicate the progression of the CPU read accesses.
When the loop reads the last accessible element, the first LED is turned on.
When the first protected element is read, a trap is raised.
The second LED is only turned on if the CPU reads a protected element.
codeExamples.abstract: The MPU is used to protect a part of an array from read/write accesses.

codeExamples.title: Multicore LED control
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC4D7_LK_ADS_Multicore
codeExamples.description:
Core 0 is switching on an LED. When the LED flag is set, Core 1 is switching off the LED.
Core 2 is controlling the state of the LED flag.
codeExamples.abstract: One LED is controlled by using three different cores.

codeExamples.title: Measuring the MCU supply voltage rails
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC4D7_LK_ADS_PMS_VMON
codeExamples.description: The Power Management System (PMS) allows the measurement of the AURIX(TM) supply voltage values by using the primary voltage monitors. In this example, a terminal application can be used to display the measured voltage values for each supply rail. CPU0 toggles an LED by using the system timer (STM).
codeExamples.abstract: The supply voltage values of the MCU are measured by the primary voltage monitors and printed to a terminal application.

codeExamples.title: iLLD_TC4D7_LK_ADS_Printf
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC4D7_LK_ADS_Printf
codeExamples.description:
The printf function is retargeted for GCC compiler to send data via ASCLIN in ASC (UART) mode.
Specific serialio library is provided for the scope.
codeExamples.abstract: The printf is used to send data with ASCLIN.

codeExamples.title: SMU triggers an interrupt upon assertion of a software alarm
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC4D7_LK_ADS_SMU_IR_Alarm
codeExamples.description:
This code example shows how to configure a reaction for a safety alarm in the Safety and Security alarm Management Unit (SMU).
In particular, an interrupt is triggered which in turn activates one of the LEDs on the board.
codeExamples.abstract: SMU_SAFE0 Software Alarm 0 triggers an interrupt request to CPU0

codeExamples.title: SPI communication via QSPI
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC4D7_LK_ADS_SPI_CPU
codeExamples.description:
QSPI0 is configured in master mode and used to send five bytes to QSPI2 configured in slave mode. The received data is read by the CPU and
compared against the transmitted data. Port pin P03.9, to which an LED is connected, indicates the successful transfer.
codeExamples.abstract: A QSPI module configured as SPI master sends five bytes to another QSPI module which is configured as SPI slave.

codeExamples.title: Interrupt generation via STM trigger
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC4D7_LK_ADS_STM_Interrupt
codeExamples.description:
The STM is configured to trigger an interrupt every 500 ms. The interrupt toggles an LED.
The STM counts up and on reaching a preconfigured compare value, it triggers an interrupt.
On each interrupt, the compare value is incremented and an LED is toggled.
codeExamples.abstract: The STM is configured to trigger an interrupt every 500 ms. The interrupt toggles an LED.

codeExamples.title: TMADC Single Channel
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC4D7_LK_ADS_TMADC_Single_Channel
codeExamples.description:
An analog input channel of Time-Multiplexed Analog-to-Digital Converter (TMADC) will be continuously converted.
When a result is available, an interrupt service request is generated.
The input value can be determined by the on-board potentiometer (R32) which is connected to AN0 pin.
Two LEDs are used to indicate a voltage interval, thus depending on the conversion value, one or both LEDs are on.
codeExamples.abstract: The TMADC is configured to continuously measure an analog signal, generating an interrupt request when a result is available.

codeExamples.title: iLLD_TC4D7_LK_ADS_Virtualization_Hypervisor
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC4D7_LK_ADS_Virtualization_Hypervisor
codeExamples.description: This project aims to provide a first user experience on new Virtualization/Hypervisor mechanism of TC4D7 Lite Kit.
codeExamples.abstract: TC4D7 Lite Kit Virtualization/Hypervisor Demonstrator

codeExamples.title: Watchdog configuration
codeExamples.name: iLLD_TC4D7_LK_ADS_Watchdog
codeExamples.description:
This example shows how to initialize and service the CPU0 Watchdog.
The Watchdog is configured to trigger a reset after approximately 1.3s if not serviced.
Pressing the on-board button stops the Watchdog from being serviced by the CPU, which then resets the device when the Watchdog timer expires.
This example also shows how to implement logical monitoring using or without using automatic password sequencing provided by WDT. In this case if a button is pressed a wrong password is provided to WDT which then resets the device.
codeExamples.abstract: The watchdog is serviced with correct password in order to prevent a reset.

codeExamples.title: Interrupts prioritization
codeExamples.name: Interrupt_Prio_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:
Each interrupt sends a message on a terminal when the ISR starts and ends.
In this example, the interrupts are triggered by GPT12 module.
codeExamples.abstract: Three interrupts, with different priorities each, send a message on a terminal using UART communication.

codeExamples.title: Interrupts prioritization
codeExamples.name: Interrupt_Prio_1_KIT_TC297_TFT
codeExamples.description:
Each interrupt is configured to control the state of one LED.
Based on their priority, the interrupts toggle the appropriate LED.
In this example, the interrupts are triggered by GPT12 module.
codeExamples.abstract: Three interrupts with different priorities are used to toggle LEDs.

codeExamples.title: PWM monitor via IOM
codeExamples.name: IOM_PWM_Monitor_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:
The PWM signal is routed through the port to the Input Output Monitor (IOM) module.
Its duty cycle is continuously compared with a threshold. If the value of the duty cycle goes
below the threshold, an LED is switched on.
codeExamples.abstract: A PWM signal's duty cycle is monitored using the IOM module.

codeExamples.title: PWM monitor via IOM
codeExamples.name: IOM_PWM_Monitor_1_KIT_TC297_TFT
codeExamples.description:

codeExamples.title: Comparison of signals via IOM
codeExamples.name: IOM_Signals_Comparison_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:
Two PWM signals are routed through the port pins to the Input Output Module (IOM) as monitor and
reference respectively. The signals are continuously compared using exclusive OR. If the newly formed
signal (XOR) is in high state outside the acceptable propagation window, an LED is switched on.
codeExamples.abstract: Two PWM signals are compared by the IOM module.

codeExamples.title: MCMCAN data transmission
codeExamples.name: MCMCAN_1_KIT_TC334_LK
codeExamples.description:
A CAN message is sent from CAN node 0 to CAN node 1 using Loop-Back mode. After the CAN message
transmission, an interrupt is generated and an LED is turned on to confirm successful message
transmission. Once the CAN message is successfully received by the CAN node 1, an interrupt is
generated. Inside the interrupt service routine the content of the received CAN message is compared to
the content of the transmitted CAN message. In case of a success, another LED is turned on to confirm
successful message reception.
codeExamples.abstract: MCMCAN is used to exchange data between two nodes, implemented in the same device using Loop-Back mode.

codeExamples.name: MCMCAN_1_KIT_TC375_LK

codeExamples.title: MCMCAN FD data transmission
codeExamples.name: MCMCAN_FD_1_KIT_TC334_LK
codeExamples.description:
The CAN messages are sent from CAN node 0 to CAN node 1 using Loop-Back mode. Both CAN nodes are set
to CAN Flexible Data-rate mode (CAN FD). After each CAN message transmission and successful reception,
an interrupt is generated. Inside the interrupt service routine, the content of the received CAN
message is read. In case of the successful read operation, the received data is compared to the
transmitted data. If all messages are received without any error detected, the LED is turned on to
confirm successful message reception.
codeExamples.abstract: MCMCAN in Flexible Data-Rate mode is used to exchange data between two nodes, implemented in the same device using Loop-Back mode.

codeExamples.title: MCMCAN acceptance filtering
codeExamples.name: MCMCAN_Filtering_1_KIT_TC334_LK
codeExamples.description:
The CAN messages are sent from CAN node 0 to CAN node 1 using Loop-Back mode.
Each transmitted CAN message contains a different message ID and based on the filter configuration,
the message is either accepted or rejected by CAN node 1. Messages that passed acceptance filtering
are stored in RX FIFOs 0 and 1 or dedicated RX buffer based on the filter configuration. Upon storing
the messages, the interrupt service routine is called and the content of the received CAN message is
read. Once the content of all the received messages is read, the received data is compared to the
transmitted data. If all messages are received without any error detected, an LED is turned on to
confirm successful message reception.
codeExamples.abstract: The initialization and configuration of several filter modes are used to illustrate different acceptance filtering options.

codeExamples.title: Memory access performance
codeExamples.name: Memory_Access_Performance_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:
A routine is implemented to execute performance measurements using the CPU performance counters.
The amount of required CPU clocks is evaluated for ten alternating write and read operations to different
memories (DSPR0, DSPR1, LMU).
codeExamples.abstract: Data is stored and read back from different RAM locations while the access times are monitored using the CPU performance counters.

codeExamples.title: MPU memory protection
codeExamples.name: MPU_Memory_Protection_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:
The MPU module is configured to enable read/write access to the first half of an array.
To test the function of the read protection, each element of the array is read in a loop.
Two LEDs are used to indicate the progression of the CPU read accesses.
When the loop reads the last accessible element, the first LED is turned on.
The second LED is only turned on if the CPU reads an element which should be protected.
codeExamples.abstract: The MPU module is used to protect part of an array from read/write accesses.

codeExamples.title: Memory Built-In Test via MTU
codeExamples.name: MTU_MBIST_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:
In this training the Memory Test Unit (MTU) is used to initialize and clear the content of an SRAM
memory including its ECC code. Also, the non destructive inversion test is performed by Memory
Built-in-Self-Test (MBIST) to verify the content of the same SRAM memory. The SRAM of the DMA
(DMARAM) is selected to be tested in this example. In order to test the faulty scenario, this training
provides the possibility to inject a single bit error in the memory. The LEDs on the board are used to
signal the correct or faulty behavior of the MBIST.
codeExamples.abstract: The MBIST is used to assess the state of the memory

codeExamples.title: MULTICAN data transmission
codeExamples.name: MULTICAN_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:
A CAN message is sent from CAN node 0 to CAN node 1 using Loop-Back mode.
After the CAN message transmission, an interrupt will be generated and LED1 will
be turned on to confirm successful message transmission. Once the CAN message
is successfully received by the CAN node 1, an interrupt will be generated.
Inside the interrupt service routine the content of the received CAN message will be
compared to the content of the transmitted CAN message. In case of a success, LED2
will be turned on to confirm successful message reception.
codeExamples.abstract: MULTICAN is used to exchange data between two nodes, implemented in the same device using Loop-Back mode.

codeExamples.title: MULTICAN data transmission
codeExamples.name: MULTICAN_1_KIT_TC297_TFT
codeExamples.description:
A CAN message is sent from CAN node 0 to CAN node 1 using Loop-Back mode.
After the CAN message transmission, an interrupt will be generated and LED1 will
be turned on to confirm successful message transmission. Once the CAN message
is successfully received by the CAN node 1, an interrupt will be generated.
Inside the interrupt service routine the content of the received CAN message will be

will be turned on to confirm successful message reception.
codeExamples.abstract: MULTICAN is used to exchange data between two nodes, implemented in the same device using Loop-Back mode.

codeExamples.title: MULTICAN FD data transmission
codeExamples.name: MULTICAN_FD_1_KIT_TC275_LK
codeExamples.description:
The CAN messages are sent from CAN node 0 to CAN node 1 using Loop-Back mode.
Both CAN nodes are set to CAN Flexible Data-rate mode (CAN FD). After each CAN message
transmission and successful reception, an interrupt is generated. Inside the interrupt service routine,
the content of the received CAN message is read. In case of the successful read operation, the
received data is compared to the transmitted data. If all messages are received without any error
detected, the LED is turned on to confirm successful message reception.
codeExamples.abstract: MULTICAN in Flexible Data-Rate mode is used to exchange data between two nodes, implemented in the same device using Loop-Back mode.

codeExamples.description:
